translation.en: [man] A lot of people say, "Carnitas is just carne."
translation.ko: 카르니타스를 그저 고기로만 생각하는 사람이 많죠

translation.en: But to me, carnitas is my life.
I remember when I was a young kid,
waking up and hearing the sound of the flame turning on.
translation.ko: 잠에서 깼는데 가스레인지의 불 켜는 소리가 들렸어요

translation.en: I knew my dad was up and ready to go to work.
I'd walk to the back,
and I could see his shadow because all the flames are on.
translation.ko: 불꽃이 만들어 낸 아버지의 그림자가 보였어요

translation.en: And my dad wouldn't even know I was there.
And I would literally sit on the fence, watching everything being cooked together.
translation.ko: 전 난간에 앉아 요리하시는 모습을 지켜봤어요

translation.en: It was just an amazing feeling of a great man.
And it just hit me. I had to help my dad.
translation.ko: 그때 알았어요 제가 아버지를 도와야 한다는 걸요

translation.en: I went inside, got ready, put my shoes on,
I was like, "Hey, Dad. I got this."
That was the first time he actually let me move the paddle.
translation.ko: 그때 처음으로 제게 장주걱을 잡게 하셨어요

translation.en: And I knew for a fact this was my destiny.
[man 2] When people think about Los Angeles,
translation.ko: 사람들은 LA라고 하면 틀에 박힌 이미지를 떠올리죠

translation.en: it's a cliche of cliches.
translation.ko: 사람들은 LA라고 하면 틀에 박힌 이미지를 떠올리죠 "할리우드"

translation.en: The great weather, surfing,
gluten-free avocado toast. But they don't know the real city.
translation.ko: 글루텐 프리 아보카도 토스트 하지만 진짜 모습은 따로 있어요

translation.en: Los Angeles is one of the most diverse cities
for eating and living in the United States.
It's a city of neighborhoods
that's been shaped by waves of immigration from Asia, Mexico, and Latin America.
translation.ko: "빌 에스파르사 '라 메히카노' 저자" LA에 와서 여러 동네를 형성했어요

translation.en: But redlining and restrictive covenants have created all these enclaves.
translation.ko: 하지만 특정 경계 지역 지정과 제한 계약 때문에 서로 섞이지 못했죠

translation.en: Because of that, you're just minutes away from the next culture.
translation.ko: 그 결과, 다양한 문화권이 몇 분 거리에 자리를 잡았어요

translation.en: And it's all connected by freeways.
[man 3] Those freeways connect you to communities
that you wouldn't otherwise have access to.
You cannot drive more than a few blocks without seeing a vendor.
translation.ko: 몇 블록만 가도 노점이 하나씩은 꼭 있어요 "매슈 강 '이터 LA' 편집장"

translation.en: And the best food in LA is on the street.
You can find dishes that you would only find in a specific region of that country,
translation.ko: 그 나라들에서도 특정 지역에서만 먹을 수 있는 음식들이에요

translation.en: like Filipino skewers,
Guatemalan tortillas, meats, and pupusas,
translation.ko: 과테말라 토르티야도 있고요 고기, 푸푸사 같은 것도 그렇죠

translation.en: Mexican dishes like quesadillas
and, of course, there are hot dogs, hamburgers.
And you see all those flavors, all those colors, all the ingredients.
translation.ko: 정말 다채로운 맛과 색과 다양한 재료를

translation.en: You see it all on the streets.
[Esparza] But of all these dishes,
translation.ko: 그중에서도 LA의 길거리 음식을 대표하는 건

translation.en: it is tacos that dominates the street food scene in Los Angeles.
translation.ko: 그중에서도 LA의 길거리 음식을 대표하는 건 타코라고 할 수 있습니다

translation.en: And one of the best ones is Carnitas El Momo in Boyle Heights,
translation.ko: 타코 맛집인 카르니타스 엘 모모는 보일 하이츠에 있어요 "카르니타스 엘 모모"

translation.en: one of the most historic and original Mexican communities.
translation.ko: 본토의 문화가 잘 보존된 유서 깊은 멕시코인 공동체죠

translation.en: [Esparza] Carnitas is soul food.
It's a style of cooking where different parts of pig
are slowly cooked in its own fat.
Takes really an expertise moving things in and out of the pot.
translation.ko: 솥에 재료를 적절히 넣고 빼는 것도 기술이에요

translation.en: There's all these different types of salsas and condiments
that, grouped together, make this incredible delicious food.
Best carnitas I ever tried, man.
translation.ko: 제가 먹어 본 것 중 최고예요

translation.en: [Esparza] And Carnitas El Momo specializes in just a handful of cuts.
translation.ko: 카르니타스 엘 모모는 몇 가지 부위만을 고집해요 "메뉴 카르니타스"

translation.en: Cuerito is the skin. Buche, hogs maw. Maciza, shoulder.
translation.ko: 쿠에리토는 껍질, 부체는 위 마시사는 어깨입니다

translation.en: And everything is so flavorful.
Romulo's children are doing the cooking now, just outside their home.
translation.ko: 지금은 로물로의 자녀들이 집 바로 밖에서 요리하죠

translation.en: And his son, Billy Acosta, has become the leader of the family,
translation.ko: 아들인 빌리 아코스타가 그 집의 가장이 됐어요

translation.en: ensuring that there's always gonna be a Carnitas El Momo in Los Angeles.
translation.ko: 카르니타스 엘 모모는 앞으로도 건재할 겁니다

translation.en: It'll always be part of the city.
-[in Spanish] Ready to exercise, or what? -Yes!
[Acosta] I'm going to do it with you.
Just watch how I do it, okay?
Counting up to 20, okay?
Ready?
One, two, three, four, five…
[Acosta in English] My father has been making carnitas for over 50 years.
It's a family thing, and it's a Mexico thing.
Yeah.
-[Romulo sighs] -In Mexico, everybody eats carnitas.
Ours are pretty simple ingredients, but the main one is love.
translation.ko: 우리 식당의 재료는 단순하지만 주재료는 사랑이죠

translation.en: The recipe that we use originated with my grandfather, Feliz Acosta.
translation.ko: 저희 할아버지 펠릭스 아코스타의 조리법을 따르고 있어요

translation.en: He did carnitas for a living in Mexico.
That's where the story started.
So my dad learns it from my grandfather.
But my dad was like a little rocker, so he didn't really dig that.
translation.ko: 반항적인 기질이 있어서 가업을 잇기 싫으셨나 봐요

translation.en: So my dad decided to come to the US with no papers,
translation.ko: 그래서 필요한 서류도 없이 미국으로 오셨죠

translation.en: you know, chasing the American dream.
And he ended up here in Los Angeles with my mom, Inocencia.
translation.ko: 그리고 제 엄마 이노센시아랑 이곳 LA로 왔어요

translation.en: He started off working as a welder, but then he got injured.
translation.ko: 처음엔 용접 일을 했는데 부상을 당하셨어요

translation.en: So he ended up having to sell carnitas to support the family.
translation.ko: 가족을 먹여 살려야 하니 카르니타스를 팔기 시작하셨죠

translation.en: Everything my dad did was to leave something for us.
translation.ko: 아버지는 저희에게 뭔가를 남겨 주려고 늘 애쓰셨어요

translation.en: And when I was growing up, we all contributed to helping my dad.
We didn't get paid for it. We did it because that's our dad.
translation.ko: 돈을 받으려고 한 게 아니라 아버지니까 도와드린 거죠

translation.en: But I learned to love it as well.
[in English] Attaboy, cowboy!
[Acosta] I didn't go to college. I don't have no degree.
translation.ko: 전 대학도 안 갔고 학위도 없어요

translation.en: With all honestly, I barely made it out of high school.
You know, and this is all I know.
translation.ko: 제가 할 줄 아는 건 이것뿐이에요

translation.en: There's no other bigger challenge than challenging myself
translation.ko: 이곳 LA 사람들에게 우리 음식이 맛있다는 걸

translation.en: to show the people here in LA that we got something good.
translation.ko: 보여주는 게 제겐 가장 큰 도전이에요

translation.en: [in Spanish] Tomorrow, I'll come, and we'll exercise more.
translation.ko: 내일 또 올 테니까 그때 또 운동해요

translation.en: -Yes. -Yeah?
Son, yes.
[in English] It's culture. It's-- It's passion. It's love. It's family. It's friends.
It's all of it together that I don't want it to die out.
translation.ko: 그 모든 게 뭉뚱그려져 있어요 전 이걸 이어 가고 싶어요

translation.en: [Kang] Food in LA, in strip malls and on the street, is incredibly rich,
translation.ko: LA엔 식당가나 길거리 음식이 굉장히 많습니다

translation.en: incredibly diverse, and just bursting with flavor.
That's where the-- the good stuff is.
And that's where people are cooking for their own community.
The breadth and the depth of how good the cuisines are,
I don't think are matched. Anywhere.
LA's Filipino community is historic. It's vast.
translation.ko: LA의 필리핀인 공동체는 유서가 깊고 크죠

translation.en: It's the largest concentration of Filipinos outside of the Philippines.
translation.ko: 해외의 필리핀인 공동체로는 세계 최대예요 "달러 히츠 - 템플"

translation.en: [woman] When you are in Dollar Hits, you feel like you're in the Philippines.
translation.ko: 저희 달러 히츠는 마치 필리핀에 있는 듯한 느낌을 주죠

translation.en: We have 33 kinds of street food in a stick.
translation.ko: 33가지의 길거리 음식을 꼬치에 꿰어 팔고 있어요 "엘비라 찬 달러 히츠"

translation.en: Everything is a dollar.
That's why it's called Dollar Hits.
A little bit joke.
We have pork barbecue, chicken barbecue, fish ball, lobster ball.
translation.ko: 돼지고기 바비큐, 닭고기 바비큐 피시 볼, 랍스터 볼

translation.en: I cannot mention everything because it's 33.
I'm a good cook because I came from Pampanga.
Pampanga is the culinary capital of the Philippines.
I came here in 1998.
Dad is an American citizen.
He was old at that time.
He always go to the hospital.
Then I would bring him food in the hospital.
In the hospital were plenty of Filipino nurses.
Told me, "Oh, the food is good!"
And then I save money,
and then me and my three sisters rent a truck.
translation.ko: 세 자매랑 같이 트럭을 하나 빌렸어요

translation.en: One day is… good.
Second day… good.
Third day is very good.
There's plenty of people there.
Then after that, sisters, we buy this market for Dollar Hits.
translation.ko: 그러다 여기 가게를 사서 달러 히츠를 낸 거예요 "달러 히츠 - 템플"

translation.en: And the Filipino people, they are happy. Everybody happy.
Everything in a stick, it's a dollar. Okay?
[Kang] Dollar Hits is probably the only place in LA
translation.ko: LA에서 제대로 된 필리핀식 꼬치구이를 파는 곳은

translation.en: where you can really get Filipino skewers.
Everything's already cooked.
You're just charring it to your preference.
translation.ko: 기호에 따라 한 번 더 구워 주는 거죠

translation.en: You get this sweet, tangy, meaty bite, and it's just like kissed with the fire.
translation.ko: 달콤하고 알싸하고 실한 꼬치에 불 맛을 입혀 줍니다

translation.en: Really get that flavor of, like,
translation.ko: 필리핀 야시장에서나 먹을 수 있는 걸

translation.en: a Filipino night market here in Los Angeles.
translation.ko: 필리핀 야시장에서나 먹을 수 있는 걸 LA에서 맛보는 거예요

translation.en: [Acosta] Growing up, my input was never taken into consideration
translation.ko: 어릴 때는 제가 어떤 의견을 내놓든

translation.en: until I grew a little older.
A Mexican household, If you're the youngest,
"Boy, get your ass back in the room and shut up," you know?
I'm the last of eight kids. I was the baby of the family.
My dad calls me…
Being the youngest, I never felt lonely
because my sister Antonia and I, we had bunk beds.
Other than that, everybody was around.
We all contributed to helping my dad.
I loved all that.
And it was always me, him, and my sister.
[sister 1 in Spanish] You didn't go anywhere?
-[sister 2] No. -No? Just stayed in?
[sister 2] No, I just went home.
[Acosta in English] The times that we were in the kitchen, cooking as a family, it was fun.
translation.ko: 식구들이랑 같이 주방에서 요리하는 게 재미있었어요

translation.en: Music playing in the background, laughing, sisters dancing on the side.
translation.ko: 음악을 틀어 놓고 웃고 떠들고 누나들은 옆에서 춤을 추고

translation.en: -[sister chuckles] -Dad's in the back, cooking the carnitas.
Mom's doing salsa in the kitchen.
It was like a fiesta, and I love that.
translation.ko: 축제 같은 그 분위기가 정말 좋았어요

translation.en: My dad, you know, he taught us that working will get you somewhere.
translation.ko: 아버지는 열심히 일하면 성공할 수 있다고 가르치셨죠

translation.en: My first job was cleaning the cazo.
It's the copper pot where you do the carnitas.
And then I moved up to cashier.
I would get nervous 'cause my dad, if I said the wrong count,
translation.ko: 계산할 땐 긴장이 됐어요 금액을 잘못 말하면

translation.en: he'd just give me this grin like, "Fool, you better get that shit right."
translation.ko: 아버지가 이렇게 웃으면서 '똑바로 안 할래?' 하셨거든요

translation.en: We weren't making millions, but we were happy with what we're doing.
translation.ko: 떼돈을 벌지는 못했지만 저희 가족은 만족했어요

translation.en: [mom in Spanish] Do you need two containers?
-[sister 1] I'll start it right now. -Oh, we need onion!
translation.ko: - 지금 바로 시작할게요 - 양파가 있어야 해

translation.en: -Yes! -The onion.
I'll do it right now.
[Acosta in English] But then, when I was ten years old, my life changed forever.
translation.ko: 10살이 되던 해에 제 인생이 완전히 달라졌어요

translation.en: [sister 1 in Spanish] ♪ When I was ♪
♪ Loving him ♪
♪ When I was feeling him ♪
♪ Fully mine ♪
♪ I saw him leave… ♪ [voice echoes, fades]
[Acosta in English] One night, my dad came into my room crying.
translation.ko: 어느 날 밤에 아버지가 울면서 제 방에 들어오셨어요

translation.en: I was scared, like, "What's going on?"
And I just hear my mom.
It was a cry of, like,
I don't know. I-- I can't imagine that pain.
translation.ko: 그 고통이 어땠을지 상상조차 안 돼요

translation.en: [sister in Spanish] ♪ He swore That he'd come back ♪
♪ But it was all a lie ♪
♪ Because his soul ♪
♪ Was no longer mine ♪
[Acosta in English] My sister, Tonia, she was involved in a car accident that instantly killed her.
It was devastating.
That-- that moment is so significant to me because…
I was so attached to my sister.
She was the light of the house, so, once we lost that light, it was darkness.
translation.ko: 늘 밝았던 누나가 떠난 후 저희 집은 불이 꺼진 듯했어요

translation.en: Behind closed doors, my dad was a very sad man.
translation.ko: 아버지는 혼자 있을 땐 굉장히 침울해하셨죠

translation.en: He was lost.
My mom, I could see her going through this endless pain
that I wanted to take away from both of them.
translation.ko: 고통을 덜어 드리고 싶은 마음이 간절했어요

translation.en: And there was times where I would literally sit outside their room,
wait until they fell asleep,
and then I would go to sleep kind of, in fear.
translation.ko: 두려움에 휩싸인 채 자러 가기도 했죠

translation.en: The happiness at home was just going downhill.
[Esparza in English] Everyone wants to come to Los Angeles for our Mexican cuisines,
translation.ko: 멕시코 음식을 먹으려고 LA를 찾는 사람이 많지만

translation.en: but people forget, we're also the largest Latino population.
translation.ko: LA의 라틴계 공동체도 세계 최대 규모입니다

translation.en: [in Spanish] I've got coconut water, strawberry juice, chocolate milk…
translation.ko: 코코넛 워터, 딸기주스 초콜릿 우유 있어요

translation.en: [Esparza in English] And Central Americans are one of the biggest parts of that.
And one of the most fantastic places in Los Angeles for Guatemalan culture,
translation.ko: LA에서 과테말라 문화와 길거리 음식을 즐길 수 있는

translation.en: Guatemalan street food, is the Guatemalan night market
translation.ko: 가장 좋은 곳 중 하나가 과테말라 야시장인데요

translation.en: located on 6th and Bonnie Brae.
It's really one of the largest centers of Central American life in Los Angeles.
translation.ko: LA에서 중앙아메리카의 삶을 제대로 느낄 수 있는 곳이죠

translation.en: You have all these vendors doing churrasco which is grilled meats,
pollo y papas, and all kinds of tamales.
translation.ko: 포요 이 파파스와 다양한 타말레도 팝니다

translation.en: And they're all lined up in rows, cooking out of shopping carts.
translation.ko: 노점상들은 줄을 지어 쇼핑 카트에서 요리를 해요

translation.en: And it's all families,
and they're there for the kind of home cooking that they miss.
translation.ko: 사람들이 그리워하는 가정식 요리를 해 주죠

translation.en: [woman in Spanish] In Guatemala, traditionally, they call it "churrasco."
It's grilled meat with beans and macaroni.
translation.ko: 콩, 마카로니와 함께 석쇠에 구운 고기예요

translation.en: Everything that we sell here, it's all Guatemalan.
I work here every day with my husband and my father-in-law.
translation.ko: 매일 남편이랑 시아버지랑 같이 나와서 일해요

translation.en: We started out just selling prepared food, walking with our carts
translation.ko: 처음엔 조리식품을 카트에 싣고 와서 팔았어요

translation.en: because the police didn't allow us to sell in this area.
translation.ko: 경찰이 이 구역에서 장사를 못 하게 했거든요 "에스테야 달레 과테말라 야시장"

translation.en: If they came, we would run away with our carts.
Sometimes they wouldn't take them. But out of spite,
translation.ko: 경찰은 카트를 빼앗지는 않아도 고기랑 콩이랑

translation.en: they would mess up all the meat, the beans, everything in the cart.
translation.ko: 카트에 있는 모든 걸 못 쓰게 만들곤 했어요

translation.en: Then we couldn't sell anything.
We kept on selling because it was our livelihood for our kids.
translation.ko: 그래도 계속 장사를 했어요 자식들을 먹여 살려야 하니까요

translation.en: Now, thankfully,
we have an organization where we can support one another.
translation.ko: 저희도 단체가 생겨서 서로를 도와줄 수 있어요

translation.en: In order to put a stop to everything that's been happening to us.
translation.ko: 그간 당해 온 부당한 일들을 막아 줄 단체가 생긴 거죠

translation.en: We have to fight, in order to succeed, one way or another.
We have to fight.
[Esparza in English] The city has been antagonistic towards street vendors.
It's an ongoing battle.
Street food was just decriminalized a few years ago in Los Angeles,
translation.ko: 노점 음식 판매가 처벌 대상에서 제외된 지 몇 년 안 됐어요

translation.en: and the legalization process has been ambiguous and expensive for vendors.
translation.ko: 노점상들 입장에선 그 과정이 답답하기도 했고 돈도 많이 들었죠

translation.en: These street vendors are not criminals. They're trusted members of our community.
translation.ko: 노점상들은 범죄자가 아니라 신뢰받는 지역사회의 일원입니다

translation.en: People love the food. They love the culture.
translation.ko: 사람들은 길거리 음식과 그들의 문화를 사랑해요

translation.en: We should be lifting up these people as the reason to come to Los Angeles,
translation.ko: 노점상들은 LA의 매력인데 힘을 주지는 못할망정

translation.en: not attacking their businesses.
[Acosta] After my sister's passing, my dad was a very sad man.
translation.ko: 누나가 죽은 후 아버지는 굉장히 침울해지셨어요

translation.en: It hurt me to see my dad like that.
That's not the man that I know.
So, I didn't wanna see him go down like that.
I felt like I could contribute to the household a little more,
translation.ko: 가족을 도울 방법이 뭐가 있을지 생각해 봤어요

translation.en: maybe help 'em with, like, whatever extra bills they had.
translation.ko: 생활비를 내는 데라도 보탬이 되고 싶었어요

translation.en: Just help.
So I decided to take this job at Canon.
A very corporate job.
All I knew is, "We got to continue living, and let's see what happens."
translation.ko: 일단은 어떻게든 삶을 유지해 나가야 했어요

translation.en: So, when I started working at the company, it was like a kid going to college.
translation.ko: 회사에 처음 들어갔을 땐 대학 신입생이 된 기분이었죠

translation.en: I learned a lot as far as marketing.
How to put a good picture out there and make people want that item.
translation.ko: 구매욕을 자극할 만한 좋은 사진을 찍는 방법

translation.en: How to present something. How to make a sale.
translation.ko: 제품을 전시하는 방법과 판매를 촉진하는 방법을요

translation.en: But at the same time, I still have carnitas always in the back of my mind.
translation.ko: 하지만 제 마음 한쪽엔 늘 카르니타스가 있었어요

translation.en: And I went to work every day with guilt.
Because I just felt like I was going away from what I'm supposed to do.
translation.ko: 제가 할 일을 회피하고 있다는 느낌이 들었거든요

translation.en: I tried to tell myself,
"It's okay, Billy." "You're working right now,
but you're doing it for the knowledge that you're learning to run a business."
And then, as a matter of fact, one day, I'm sweeping, and I'm full of dust,
translation.ko: 그러던 어느 날 먼지투성이가 돼서 청소를 하고 있는데

translation.en: and a friend, he walks towards me and he's like, "Hey."
"What the fuck are you doing?" Just like that.
translation.ko: '야, 너 뭐 하는 거냐?' 뜬금없이 그랬어요

translation.en: And I'm like, "Oh, I'm sweeping 'cause we gotta return this warehouse."
He's like, "No. What the fuck are you doing with your life?"
He's like, "Look at yourself. You're full of dust."
"Are you gonna work here for the rest of your life or what are you gonna do?"
And he just walked away.
And I just stood there thinking, like, "What the fuck am I doing?"
translation.ko: 저도 생각해 봤어요 '나 진짜 뭐 하는 거냐?'

translation.en: And then I gave my two-week notice.
[Kang] I think one thing that is still true about LA
translation.ko: LA에서 변하지 않은 점 중 하나는

translation.en: is that it is a place where you pursue an opportunity.
It's a destination for creative people,
for dreamers.
It's still very much what makes the city awesome.
translation.ko: 그래서 이 도시가 여전히 근사한 거고요

translation.en: ♪ We need ♪
translation.ko: "핫도그 쇠고기, 닭고기, 비건" "로스앤젤레스, 얼스 온 크렌쇼"

translation.en: ♪ Peace… ♪
At Earle's, if you order a hot dog, they split it just right,
translation.ko: 얼스에서 핫도그를 주문하면 소시지를 반 갈라

translation.en: so it lands on the grill and it gets exposure to the fire on both sides.
translation.ko: 양면이 다 불에 노출되도록 석쇠에서 굽습니다

translation.en: And then, right before they serve it, the chef takes a knife, and he'll actually score it, you know,
translation.ko: 그리고 손님에게 내기 직전에 칼집을 내죠

translation.en: so the whole thing is just maximum grill flavor.
translation.ko: 석쇠 구이 특유의 풍미를 극대화하는 겁니다

translation.en: They take a lot of care into making something simple, super good.
translation.ko: 단순한 음식이지만 공들여 만드니 굉장히 맛있죠

translation.en: Earle's restaurant started as a hot dog cart,
translation.ko: 얼스는 원래 핫도그 카트였고 "두에인 얼 얼스 온 크렌쇼"

translation.en: actually almost 40 years now, in the Crenshaw community,
where we still remain in this community, to this day.
It's a three-man operation. My brother's busy in the back.
translation.ko: 3명이 운영해요 제 형제는 안에서 요리를 하고

translation.en: I'm busy, the front man, doing my thing. My mom is that gracious host.
translation.ko: 전 앞쪽에서 일하고 어머니는 손님들을 상대하시죠

translation.en: Yeah, I could eat it out here.
[Earle] I left New York in the mid-'80s. I got a phone call from my brother.
translation.ko: 뉴욕에 살던 80년대 중반에 형제에게서 전화를 받았어요

translation.en: He told me, "Come on out here. It's beautiful."
"The weather's great. I'm doing a hot-dog business."
It was kinda like, "Hey, let me come to LA and start off fresh."
translation.ko: 'LA에 가서 새로 시작해 볼까' 하는 생각이 들더라고요

translation.en: It was your typical "come out to Hollywood to be a star" type thing.
translation.ko: 스타의 꿈을 품고 할리우드로 가는 사람처럼요

translation.en: Only, in my case, I was rapping.
I used to always rap at the hot dog cart.
I'd make a hot dog and rap against somebody.
I eventually ended up signing with Ice Cube.
So I actually got best of both worlds,
was able to be part of the business, for this continuous amount of time,
and I was able to get in the music industry also.
[man] Crenshaw is about art, history.
It's been Black. It's been Hispanic. It's been Asian.
There's a lot of good people here.
So It's been very important for us to stay here because these people support us.
translation.ko: 응원해 주는 사람들을 위해서라도 여길 지키려고 노력해 왔어요

translation.en: We've had customers that grew up on our hot dogs.
translation.ko: 저희 핫도그를 먹고 자란 손님들도 있거든요

translation.en: So we put a lot of time into what we do.
translation.ko: "케리 얼 얼스 온 크렌쇼" 공들여 음식을 만듭니다

translation.en: We love what we do, and it shows in our food.
translation.ko: 저희가 이 일을 좋아한다는 건 저희 음식을 먹어 보면 알죠

translation.en: [Earle] People know our name.
We know the postman, the postwoman, the fireman.
We are that part of the community.
Funny as it may seem, we're like the Black Cheers of LA.
translation.ko: 주민들이 편하게 오가는 아지트라고도 할 수 있어요

translation.en: ♪ Booty big and round Just like an apple, apple ♪
♪ Teacher pet He gave his teacher apple, apple ♪
translation.ko: 범생이가 선생님께 드린 건 애플, 애플

translation.en: ♪ Should have invested My money with Apple, Apple ♪
translation.ko: 내가 투자했어야 할 그곳은 애플, 애플

translation.en: -[in Spanish] We once went to a dance. -Yup! We went to a dance.
-[Inocencia] It was March 18th, right? -Yes, my darling.
[Inocencia] And that's when he said that I'd make him the happiest man on earth,
translation.ko: 내가 여자 친구가 돼 주면 자긴 세상에서 가장 행복한

translation.en: if I agreed to be his girlfriend.
And I said, "Is he telling the truth?"
[Acosta in English] All my life, till this day,
translation.ko: 제가 평생 봐 온 부모님은 늘 가족을 돌보기 위해

translation.en: my parents, they did what they had to do to take care of our family.
translation.ko: 제가 평생 봐 온 부모님은 늘 가족을 돌보기 위해 열심히 일하셨어요

translation.en: And so, after I quit my job,
I came to my dad, and I said, "I'm ready to do this."
translation.ko: 아버지한테 와서 그랬죠 '이걸 할 준비가 됐어요'

translation.en: "I'm ready to face the world with the carnitas business."
He said, "About time! I've been waiting for this."
translation.ko: 제가 그 말을 하길 기다렸다고 하시더군요

translation.en: I love you, Mom.
[Acosta] And I never seen him smile more.
translation.ko: 그렇게 활짝 웃으시는 건 처음 봤어요

translation.en: Like, he was proud.
Once he gave me his okay and his blessing…
…I felt fulfilled.
My parents, they were ready to let me take the steering wheel now.
translation.ko: 부모님은 제게 지휘권을 넘길 준비가 돼 있으셨죠

translation.en: I kept my dad's recipe exactly the same because people loved it.
translation.ko: 전 아버지의 조리법을 고수했어요 사람들이 그걸 좋아했거든요

translation.en: Crispy on the outside, tender on the inside,
just melting in your mouth.
But the first thing I did change was we bought this lunch truck.
translation.ko: 제가 제일 먼저 바꾼 건 이 푸드 트럭을 산 거죠

translation.en: Because, before, it was just a little spot on a porch,
translation.ko: 그냥 집 앞의 작은 공간에서 장사를 하다가 트럭이 생기니

translation.en: and it felt like we had something now.
So now we start adding a few more days.
Thursdays through Sundays, not just selling on the weekends.
And then we started adding dishes to the menu.
Like birria de res,
and mulitas, which is a layer of meat, cheese, and then a tortilla.
translation.ko: 고기, 치즈를 토르티야에 싸서 만드는 물리타도요

translation.en: And then I started taking really good pictures of the carnitas,
translation.ko: 그다음엔 카르니타스 사진을 아주 먹음직스럽게 찍어서

translation.en: then putting them out there on social media.
My parents would trip out, like, 'cause I would sit the mulitas crossed,
translation.ko: 부모님은 기겁하셨어요 제가 물리타를 겹쳐 놓고

translation.en: and, like, I'll put the torta there, and I'll take pictures of it.
They would look at me, like, "What is this guy doing?"
translation.ko: 이해할 수 없다는 표정으로 절 보곤 하셨죠

translation.en: And my mom would laugh at me.
[in Spanish] Why you doing this?
[in English] And I'm like, "You have to put the picture out there."
"You have to make it look good." And she'll laugh.
But people were loving the fact that we were adding
a little more swag to the lunch truck.
And then the momentum starts to build.
The demand got higher. We started getting attention.
And that's how, uh, we caught the eye of Bill Esparza.
translation.ko: 그러다 빌 에스파르사의 눈에 띄게 됐어요

translation.en: [in Spanish] Hi!
Hi, Bill! Good afternoon! How are you?
-I'm well. -So good to see you!
How are you all?
-[in English] Working hard, like always -All right. You know what I want.
translation.ko: - 매일 부지런히 일하죠 - 주문은 뭔지 아시죠?

translation.en: -[in Spanish] Tell me. -Carnitas.
Of course. How many would you like?
[Esparza in English] When I went to Momo for the first time, I was blown away.
translation.ko: 모모에 처음 갔던 날 깜짝 놀랐습니다

translation.en: Order for Bill?
[Esparza] It's absolutely just brilliant.
Thank you, man.
And I had that bite, and everything was so tender and so flavorful,
translation.ko: 한입 물었는데 얼마나 부드럽고 풍미 넘치던지

translation.en: with just some pickled jalapenos.
It's as good as you'll find in Mexico.
It has grittiness and soul and luxury, all in one.
translation.ko: 거칠함, 소울, 화려함이 그 안에 다 들어 있었어요

translation.en: And I thought, everyone needs to know about this place.
But as a Mexican American writer,
sometimes I have to be a little bit of an activist.
So I invited them to the festival I hosted at the time, Tacolandia,
translation.ko: 제가 개최한 타코란디아 축제에 이분들을 초대했어요

translation.en: where chefs from all over competed for the title of best taco.
translation.ko: 각지의 셰프들이 와서 타코 실력을 겨루는 행사예요

translation.en: [Acosta] At that time, if you wanna be noticed in LA, you had to be in Tacolandia.
translation.ko: 당시 LA에서 주목받으려면 타코란디아에 출전해야 했어요

translation.en: And Tacolandia gets some of the best chefs in LA, Baja, and North Cal.
translation.ko: 타코란디아에는 LA, 바하칼리포르니아와 북부 캘리포니아 최고의 셰프들이 오죠

translation.en: And that was challenging and intimidating.
Seeing all these people in their chef coats, their chef hats.
translation.ko: 다들 셰프의 옷을 입고 셰프의 모자를 쓰고 있는데

translation.en: I'm a taquero. I'm a carnicero, you know?
I was going like this. My shirt, hat, that's it.
But then, I was just like, "Man, fuck this!"
"I'm gonna make sure that these fucking carnitas are on point."
translation.ko: '이렇게 된 거, 진짜 맛있는 카르니타스를 만들어야지'

translation.en: "Let's go."
And then, when I started cooking the carnitas,
I could feel some type of good energy just flowing around there.
translation.ko: 좋은 에너지가 주변을 감싸고 흐르는 것 같았어요

translation.en: My father, guiding me, just speaking to me like,
"Watch the way you move the pala."
"Move it here."
"Lower the flame."
"Watch it," you know, like, I-- I can't explain it.
translation.ko: '잘 봐' 이런 식으로요 이건 설명이 안 돼요

translation.en: Everything came into picture.
The struggle of my family, you know.
The sadness, the happiness.
Going back to the kitchen, everybody dancing, everybody prepping salsa.
translation.ko: 주방에서 모두가 춤추고 살사를 준비하던 일

translation.en: My sister Tonia still around, my dad smiling.
translation.ko: 안토니아 누나가 살아 있고 아버지가 미소 지으시던 때

translation.en: All that came into play that day,
translation.ko: 그날 그 모든 순간이 하나가 됐고

translation.en: and… [sighs] …we ended up winning 2017.
I remember them announcing it on the speaker, you know,
"Winner of today Tacolandia, Carnitas El Momo."
My dad started crying.
And then I started crying.
That's when I knew, like, this is my life.
That's my family.
I cook carnitas, and I love what I do,
but it's their story that I'm trying to tell, you know?
translation.ko: 거기엔 제 가족의 이야기가 담겨 있어요

translation.en: [Esparza] The success of Carnitas El Momo is really the proper icon for Los Angeles.
translation.ko: 카르니타스 엘 모모의 성공은 아주 LA다운 현상입니다

translation.en: It means that our food now represents the city that's our city.
translation.ko: 우리의 음식이 우리의 도시를 반영한다는 뜻이에요

translation.en: Our street vendors are incredible,
making recipes that are multi-generational
translation.ko: 여러 세대의 호응을 받는 조리법을 개발해서

translation.en: to keep their culture alive.
It's really about being seen.
[Dalé in Spanish] I think it's just the way we cook.
Everything we do, we put our heart into it.
I've always enjoyed serving the customers,
translation.ko: 전 손님들에게 음식을 대접하고 다양한 손님들이 제 음식을 만족스럽게 먹는 게 좋아요

translation.en: and that they feel satisfied, regardless of where they come from.
translation.ko: 다양한 손님들이 제 음식을 만족스럽게 먹는 게 좋아요 "과테말라 포요 이 파파스 프라이드 치킨과 감자"

translation.en: [Kang in English] In LA, street food is extremely rich and intense,
translation.ko: LA엔 길거리 음식이 정말 많고 수준도 높죠

translation.en: and reflective of the people that come here.
It is a way to see a totally new world.
translation.ko: 길거리 음식을 통해 새로운 세상을 접할 수 있어요

translation.en: [Chan] When I'm working, I put in my heart.
When I see people around, especially Filipino, oh my God!
I am happy, and I am blessed.
[Esparza] Street food, it's a family endeavor, family operation.
That's the people you can count on and trust.
What are you gonna have, sweetheart?
And the customers, they've really become extended family and extended community.
translation.ko: 손님들은 가족이나 지역사회의 일원 같은 존재가 됐어요

translation.en: [Earle] If you came up to me, and you were short on some cash, and you wanted chili,
translation.ko: 손님이 돈이 없는데 칠리가 먹고 싶다면

translation.en: your chili was on me.
We've actually become an intricate, sewn piece of fabric into the community.
Really, really sewn into the community.
[Esparza] Street food is vital to Los Angeles.
These vendors, they are what makes Los Angeles the best city for food.
translation.ko: LA를 음식의 도시로 만드는 주역은 노점들이에요

translation.en: [Kang] They've established something, and now you can't have LA without street food.
translation.ko: 길거리 음식이 없는 LA는 상상조차 할 수 없어요

translation.en: [in English] Thank you.
[man] I need cheese, please.
[woman] Here you are. Thanks so much!
[Acosta] You want a carnitas taco?
[Romulo] All pork skin.
Yup, make it.
Make it! Make it!
[Acosta in English] In 2018, my parents take a trip to Europe.
That was their first-ever vacation, 15-day trip.
And a day before they flew back to the US,
my dad got the stroke.
It was sad.
It hurt me to see my dad like that.
[Acosta in English] And now, he can't really do much anymore.
But we're blessed to still have him here.
And since then, he's become stronger.
I believe my dad is happy to know that we're continuing what his father started.
translation.ko: 할아버지가 시작하신 일을 저희가 이어 가고 있어서 기쁘실 거예요

translation.en: Now I feel like that moment in my life, when I seen him alone in the back,
cooking by himself.
Now, I fill in those shoes.
Now I'm in the back, and I'm alone,
and I feel like I have to provide for the family.
But it's okay. I love that feeling.
I believe it's destiny.
Now I think it's time for me to take care of him.
I'm here to help them, and I'm here to help them forever.
[Inocencia in Spanish] Hand in hand.
Forever.
[Romulo] The future.
Forever. Forever.
[in English] Portland is like the biggest version of the kids' table.
translation.ko: 포틀랜드는 커다란 아이들 식탁 같은 곳입니다 "포틀랜드"

translation.en: No one's looking over your shoulder and telling you what to do,
and anything is game.
That's just so damn Portland.
